awd_titl_txt: CBASS-South: Completing the C-Band All Sky Survey for the Southern Skies
awd_abstract_narration:
The objective of the program is to complete the analysis (and release) of maps of the southern half of an all sky radio (5 GHz frequency) intensity and polarization survey. This will aid in the removal of contaminating foregrounds from Cosmic Microwave Background (CMB) studies and will also provide information about our Galaxy's Interstellar Medium (ISM) and magnetic fields.  Broader impacts include training of students in instrumentation, international collaboration with students, and a broad outreach program targeting audiences from a variety of age groups and cultural backgrounds. Members of the proposing team play an important role in the development and execution of these programs.

The C-Band All Sky Survey (C-BASS) is a radio survey at 5 GHz of the entire sky in total intensity and linear polarization, with resolution of 0.73 degrees, sensitivity of about 0.1 mK rms, and minimal corruption by instrumental systematic errors. The award will allow C-BASS to fulfill its primary goals of characterizing emission mechanisms of the ISM, determining an all-sky template for polarized emission from the Galaxy, and allowing for more accurate separation of intrinsic CMB signals from foreground emission, thus enabling CMB polarization experiments to realize their full potential. CMB polarization is being measured from space by the Planck satellites, and by several current and future ground-based and balloon-borne experiments supported by NSF, NASA, DOE and other agencies.

por.por_cntn:
The C-band All Sky Survey (C-BASS) is a project to map the cosmic radio emission from the entire sky at a frequency of 5 GHz, where the emission is dominated by diffuse synchrotron radiation from cosmic rays and magnetic fields in our Galaxy. It is conducted in two overlapping parts: a survey of the northern sky from an antenna at the Owens Valley Radio Observatory in California and a survey of the southern sky from a similar antenna in South Africa. It is a collaboration of the California Institute of Technology in the United States, the Universities of Manchester and Oxford in the United Kingdom, and the South African Radio Astronomy Observatory. 

With support from this award the collaboration has completed the analysis of the northern survey and prepared the results for data release and publication. The data release will include maps of the northern sky in total intensity and linear polarization (Stokes parameters I, Q, and U) with a resolution of about 45 arcmin, and "deconvolved" maps with a Gaussian point-spread function with a full-width half-maximum of 1 degree. There are also a catalog of extragalactic point sources and maps with these sources subtracted to facilitate analysis of the diffuse emission.

Unfortunately the collaboration was not able to complete the southern survey, owing to the COVID-19 pandemic, which prevented access to the southern antenna.

The primary motivation for the survey was to facilitate removal of foreground emission arising in our Galaxy from the Cosmic Microwave Background radiation (CMB) arising soon after the Big Bang. The polarization of the CMB carries important information in its "B-mode" about the early state of the Universe and the period of rapid inflation that is believed to have occurred before the formation of the stars, galaxies and other structures that now populate the Universe. The CMB polarization has been measured by the WMAP and Planck satellite missions, but is contaminated by foreground emission from the Galaxy. The C-BASS observations have been used to predict the contamination of CMB observations at about 100 GHz where the CMB polarization is most readily detected, and to show that no part of the sky is free from synchrotron contamination at a level sufficient to measure or place useful limits on the B-mode CMB polarization signal. To measure the CMB polarization accurately it is necessary to carefully model and subtract the contaminating signals. This requires measuring the foregrounds at a wide range of frequencies, and C-BASS will be essential for tying down the synchrotron part of the foreground radiation.

The C-BASS maps are also important for understanding the structure of the Galactic interstellar medium and magnetic field. In conjunction with observations at other frequencies C-BASS can map the Faraday rotation measure and hence the magnetic field strength and orientation. With observations of the dust-induced polarization of stars and using the distances to stars obtained from the GAIA satellite mission C-BASS will provide essential data for understanding the three-dimensional structure of the Galactic magnetic field. The maps also provide measurements and constraints on the "anomalous microwave emission" in our Galaxy and in the Andromeda Galaxy; this emission is still poorly understood but is attributed to spinning dust grains.

The project has fostered a successful international collaboration including several graduate students and postdoctoral scholars who have received training in radio astronomy and cosmology and have traveled between the institutions. In the period of the award three students have been awarded PhDs for work on C-BASS.
